text: it all depends on what their goals are with the content - one way isn't necessarily better than another, it's about results. i'd dig in to how content fits in to the bigger picture strategy, and why they decided to revamp content / what wasn't working before.

elements.text: it all depends on what their goals are with the content - one way isn't necessarily better than another, it's about results. i'd dig in to how content fits in to the bigger picture strategy, and why they decided to revamp content / what wasn't working before.

text: It’s better to be word count agnostic and let the SERP guide you. With your audience I imagine you need to be as concise as possible. Conveying the maximum amount of information in the least amount of words is a great way to illustrate your expertise. Using that example and comparing it against SERP competition, you do have a good Content Score to Word Count ratio. However you could expand coverage on that topic to make it more comprehensive than other sources, while still maintaining a degree of concision.

elements.text: It’s better to be word count agnostic and let the SERP guide you. With your audience I imagine you need to be as concise as possible. However you could expand coverage on that topic to make it more comprehensive than other sources, while still maintaining a degree of concision.

text:
I've created an infographic to live inside a blog post I've written.

Do you a) just leave the infographic as the section b) add a text commentary or c) something else?

This is currently the top and bottom. Ideally, I want to be as inclusive as possible. But fear I'm taking up too much real estate.

elements.text:
I've created an infographic to live inside a blog post I've written.

Do you a) just leave the infographic as the section b) add a text commentary or c) something else?

This is currently the top and bottom. Ideally, I want to be as inclusive as possible. But fear I'm taking up too much real estate.

text:
Hey Dom!

The only “text commentary” I would add would be a credit for the infographic, in case someone else on the web finds and uses it. That way you’ll at least get some attribution on it.

elements.text:
Hey Dom!

The only “text commentary” I would add would be a credit for the infographic, in case someone else on the web finds and uses it. That way you’ll at least get some attribution on it.

text:
Hey!

Looking for any advice on how you share your content internally and make it accessible (esp. for sales and CS usage!!). I do the standard Slack sparknotes on any new piece of content, but we're at a high-growth company with new faces and it's not the most effective method now. What strategies do you use to make all of your content housed in an easy-to-find location beyond our own blog page or podcast feed?

elements.text:

Looking for any advice on how you share your content internally and make it accessible (esp. for sales and CS usage!!). What strategies do you use to make all of your content housed in an easy-to-find location beyond our own blog page or podcast feed?

text:
Following, because it’s been a challenge for us as well.

One thing we’ve done is create a large database of all published content, denoting content type (blog, case study, etc.) along with who it’s for and what product use case it addresses. But still feels like we could be taking an additional step to get it better in front of folks.

elements.text:

text:
Hey Adam!

I’ve actually heard of some success being had with creating an internal Notion database with the team and “dumping” content there. The company I work for currently uses Notion as something of a “catch-all” to help make company documentation accessible in one spot, and I’ve heard of Marketing teams using it as well for building, maintaining, and team-managing content

text: I've seen Guru, Seismic, and Newscred (now Welcome) used for this - to varying levels of effectiveness. And certainly you could put somethin together with Notion like this. Adoption & maintenance tend to be issues

text: <@U016AG4A2G2> adoption and maintenance are indeed issues! That's the nut to be cracked right now (maybe there's something in the market that solves this... if not there's a biz idea for free!). I'll take a look at those options as well and see if I can find any success stories

text:
I create a weekly content digest email that summarizes all content produced (content, PR, social) in the previous week, as well as a monthly content report that displays content performance. For extremely demand-gen oriented content (ebooks, templates, webinars), I email teams individually (Sales, BDRs, Customer Success, e.g.)

We are currently evaluating Seismic, HighSpot, and PathFactory to better "house" and analyze content for our Sales team.

EDIT: Adding this, all of our resources are also in Sharepoint, etc., although it's a constant task to remind people where these items are located in the share drive.

text: I'm actually working on this problem right now as well. As <@U01S7E3C7MG> has mentioned, content taxonomy becomes pretty important to enable searching. That works well & good within the CMS, but doesn't work at all for sales people & CS. Following along here to see if anyone has had any success implementing something that would integrate with a CRM like HubSpot or others

text: Guru, Confluence, Notion, etc. -- whatever you're using for internal documentation. But in many cases, you have to treat it like external content (create with distro in mind, etc.)

text: If your company or you personally have a podcast, what stage did you decide "we're ready for sponsorships" or started to sell ad slots?

text: Tagging content in a Notion database so people can just filter by topics and content types has worked for me in the past. And also to keep people updated on new content, a team I work with has a dedicated #content channel in Slack to share updates.

elements.text: Tagging content in a Notion database so people can just filter by topics and content types has worked for me in the past. And also to keep people updated on new content, a team I work with has a dedicated #content channel in Slack to share updates.

text: For my personal podcast, immediately.  I knew the caliber of guests would draw a good sponsor and pay for the entire production time and materials.

elements.text: For my personal podcast, immediately.  I knew the caliber of guests would draw a good sponsor and pay for the entire production time and materials.

text: We're just now starting to consider it after 30 episodes and building up a little audience. Probably won't actually do sponsors for a while - want to focus on maximizing listener value first

elements.text: We're just now starting to consider it after 30 episodes and building up a little audience. Probably won't actually do sponsors for a while - want to focus on maximizing listener value first

text: Echoing Jimmy, depends on a lot: website strength, ability to rank on BoFu, conversion pathways / product go to market, timeline to expect ROI, etc. We always proportion this out according to the "Barbell" portfolio allocation (heavier ToFu/buzzworthy if the company is earlier stage, mostly BoFu if they have a strong site and can just rank easily) <https://www.alexbirkett.com/the-barbell-strategy-content-marketing/>

attachments.title: The Barbell Strategy for Risk-Averse Content Marketing
attachments.text: “Marry an accountant, but have occasional flings with rock stars.” - Nassim Nicholas Taleb The worst thing that can happen to a marketer embarking on setting up a content program is also the most common. It goes like this: The Death Spiral of Nearly All Content Programs You see some
attachments.fallback: Alex Birkett: The Barbell Strategy for Risk-Averse Content Marketing
